results.title: Barry Humphries' flashbacks [DVD]
results.creator_credit: David Mitchell, John McLean, ABC-TV (Australia) and Flashback Films
results.brief_description: Entertainer and self confessed cultural historian Barry Humphries takes the viewer on a voyage of discovery into Australian society in the 1950s, 60s, 70s and 80s. Relive choice moments from the following decades such as; Menzies, music through the ages, Petrov, Queen Elizabeth, Coronation, soapies’ sophistication, decimal currency, Aussie inventions, television, the 1956 Olympic Games, republicanism, quizshows, Beatniks, Australian images overseas, advertising, the Melbourne Cup, charm schools, rock stars, immigration, demolition, the Sydney Opera House, Harold Holt, pubs, police, contraception, American servicemen, Alvin Purple, “Number 96”, the Logies, plus many other memorable moments. Humphries is assisted in this discovery by some special friends; Dame Edna Everage, Sandy Stone, and Sir Les Patterson. Also available on VHS [309408]

results.title: Barnum (Musical)
results.creator_credit: Terry Hughes, Harold Fielding and BBC
results.brief_description: The stage production starring Michael Crawford of ‘Barnum!’ recorded in 1986 when the hit circus musical was performed at the Victoria Palace in London’s West End. The story traces Phineas Taylor Barnum’s colourful career during 1835 to 1881, from his beginnings as a promoter of sideshows to the pinnacle of his success after he joined James A. Bailey to form the circus which was known as ‘The Greatest Show on Earth’. Featuring 14 musical numbers with music by Cy Coleman and lyrics by Michael Stewart. Original Broadway production directed by Joe Layton, the production cast also includes Christine Collier, Sharon Benson and Eileen Battye.

results.title: Barnum
results.creator_credit: David J. Patterson, Ira Halberst, Lee Philips, Filmline International and Robert Halmi Productions
results.brief_description: Made-for-television film that chronicles the life of 19th-century American showman and circus operator Phineas T. Barnum. Beginning in 1883 with an eager audience awaiting the opening of Barnum & Bailey’s “Greatest Show on Earth,” the film flashes foward to an elderly Barnum, then back, as he recalls his life story from his early days in New England to his time as a freak-show hustler and his ultimate triumph as a big time impressario. Barnum’s famous motto was, “give them entertainment and let them enjoy themselves.” A stage-musical version of Barnum’s story made in 1986 is also held in the collection.

results.title: Barefoot adventure
results.creator_credit: Bruce Brown and Bruce Brown Films
results.brief_description: This re-construction by the maker of “Endless Summer” (1966), of his third surfing film (originally released in 1960), features footage taken at some of the best longboarding beaches in Hawaii and California. Bruce Brown, developed the surf film genre (which originated in Australia) by adding a slight narrative line and a light-hearted commentary. From the late fifties to the early seventies Brown made nine surfing films which he roadshowed across America, screening them in local halls, theatres and school auditoriums, and providing live improvised commentary. The soundtrack for this and a number of Brown’s other surf films were composed by jazz legend Bud Shank and performed with his quartet.

results.title: Barchester Chronicles
results.creator_credit: David Giles, Jonathan Powell and BBC
results.brief_description: An adaptation of Anthony Trollope’s two 19th Century classics, “The Warden”, and “Barchester Towers”, starring Donald Pleasence, Nigel Hawthorne, Geraldine McEwan and Susan Hampshire. Reverend Septimus Harding is one of the most respected men in Barchester. He lives an honest and undisturbed life until the advent of a passionate reformer, John Bold, who accuses the Reverend of corruption which turns his cosy world of Barchester upside down.

results.title: Barcelona [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Whit Stillman and New Visions Pictures
results.brief_description: An off-beat and ironic talk-fest from director Whit Stillman, this is a dry, insightful comedy about two American cousins in post-Franco Spain. Ted Boynton, an overly serious salesman, who is in the midst of recovering from a broken relationship and questioning his vocation originally inspired by an Arthur Miller play, is suddenly faced with the arrival of his arrogant navy cousin Fred. What ensues is a series of intensive bar crawls where the cousins encounter a group of women from the Trade Centre, one of whom Ted promptly falls in love with. A study of the life and attitudes of two Americans abroad underlies this comic romantic tale through which the film takes on a more serious satirical tone. As the film progresses, the ineptitude of Ted and Fred to integrate with the values of the culture they inhabit is only exceeded by the anti-American sentiment in Spain which the characters do not remain untouched by, but are slow to recognise. This film will no doubt appeal to fans of Whit Stillman’s characteristic distanced play between amusement and substantial critique.

results.title: Barcelona
results.brief_description: A practical guide for travellers intending to visit the Catalonian region of Spain. Beginning in Barcelona, host John Guerrasio provides information about public transport options, accommodation, food and currency. He visits the 1992 Olympic precinct, the Joan Miro Gallery situated on Monjuic and the Ramblas. From Barcelona, he travels to Montserrat, Tarragona, the Costa Brava and Gerona highlighting the main areas of cultural and geographic interest. Also includes a visit to Antonio Gaudi’s Sagrada Familia.

results.title: Baraka [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ron Fricke, Mark Magidson and Magidson Films
results.brief_description: Shot in 24 countries, “Baraka” is an extraordinary visual feast that examines the passionate and destructive love/hate relationship between humans and earth. A spectacular diversity of memorable images have been gathered from around the world from the natural and man-made environments, both past and present. The style is strongly reminiscent of the film “Koyaanisqatsi” in its use of timelapse photography juxtaposed with slower sequences, and the somewhat sentimental, simplistic portrayal of humanity.

results.title: Barbed wire and mandolins
results.creator_credit: Nicola Zaraglia, Sam Grana and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: When Italy became an active player in the Second World War in 1940, the Canadian government began to fear the Italian community within Canada as a threat to national security. The action they took was to use the Canadian Mounted Police Force to contain alleged facist sympathizers. Seven hundred of the accused sympathizers were held in internment camps for up to three years. The majority of detainees were held at Petawawa, Ontario. Through interviewing Italian-Canadians who were affected by these actions, one discovers that there was a spirit of camaraderie and hope amongst those at Petawawa as the internees coped with their situation in the any way they could, such as through music, art and gardening. Despite these diversions, what they have lost financially and socially in the community remains with them forever.

results.title: Bangers
results.brief_description: A working woman arrives home to the apartment she shares with her mother to discover that the cat has been locked inside - again. It is a stark reminder of her mundane existence, and to make matters worse, sausages are on the menu again. As she cooks up the bangers she lets out all of her frustration. Cast includes Cate Blanchett and Lynette Curran as the mother and daughter.
